parse.title: Timeline of the Kingdom of Jerusalem

text.*:
The Kingdom of Jerusalem, other crusader states and their neighbors in 1135

The timeline of the Kingdom of Jerusalem presents important events of the history of the Kingdom of Jerusalem in chronological order. The kingdom was a crusader state, established during the First Crusade in Palestine in 1099. Its first ruler, Godfrey of Bouillon, was never crowned. He acknowledged the claim of the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, Daimbert, to sovereignty. Godfrey's brother and successor, Baldwin of Boulogne was crowned the first king of Jerusalem in 1100. He subjected the Latin patriarchs to his rule and achieved that the rulers of other crusader states—the County of Edessa, the County of Tripoli and the Principality of Antioch—obey to his commands. Fleets from Pisan, Genoese and Venice supported Baldwin I and his successors to capture all the towns on the coast. The crusaders (or Franks) also contolled the caravan routes between Egypt and Syria.

The polarisation of the Muslim world enabled the Franks to consolidate their rule in Palestine. They could also appeal to the Popes and the European rulers for help. Baldwin III and Amalric maintained a close alliance with the Byzantine Empire, but they could not prevent Nur ad-Din from uniting the Muslim states in Syria in the 1150s. Nur ad-Din also began the unification of Syria and Egypt, and the process was completed by Saladin in the 1180s. Amalric's successors, the leper Baldwin IV and the unpopular Guy of Lusignan could not hinder the disintegration of the kingdom. Saladin annihilated the crusader army in the Battle of Hattin on July 4, 1187 and captured most towns (including Jerusalem) during the following months. An Italian crusader, Conrad of Montferrat, saved Tyre and Guy of Lusignan laid siege to Acre in 1189. The Third Crusade secured the survival of the kingdom and Saladin acknowledged that most coastal towns remained under Frank rule in his truce with Richard I of England.

Background[edit]

Further information: Crusades
"Oh, race of Franks, ... race chosen and beloved by God... ! ... From the confines of Jerusalem and the city of Constantinople a horrible tale has gone forth and very frequently has been brought to our ears, namely, that a race from the kingdom of the Persians, an accursed race, ... has invaded the lands of those Christians and has depopulated them by the sword, pillage and fire... . They destroy the altars, after having defiled them with their uncleanness. They circumcise the Christians, and the blood of the circumcision they either spread upon the altars or pour into the vases of the baptismal font. ... What shall I say of the abominable rape of the women? To speak of it is worse than to be silent. The kingdom of the Greeks is now dismembered by them... . On whom therefore is the labor of avenging these wrongs and of recovering this territory incumbent, if not upon you?"

A version of Pope Urban II's sermon at the Council of Clermont (from Robert the Monk's Historia Hierosolymitana)

"[Emperor Alexios I Komnenos] was seated, as was his custom, looking powerful on the throne of his sovereignty... [Duke Godfrey of Bouillon] bowed down with bended knee, and his men also bowed down to kiss the exceedingly glorious and powerful emperor. Then when everyone had been kissed according to rank he spoke to the duke in these words: "I have heard about you that you are a very powerful knight and prince in your land, and a very wise man and completely honest. Because of this I am taking you as my adopted son, and I am putting everything I possess in your power, so that my empire and land can be freed and save through you from the present and future multitudes." The duke was pleased and beguilded by the emperor's peaceful and affectionate words, and he not only gave himself as a son, ... but even as a vassal with hands joined... ."

Godfrey of Bouillon swears fealty to Alexios I Komnenos (from Albert of Aachen's Historia Hierosolymitanae expeditionis)

1009

  • September 27. The Fatimid caliph Al-Hakim (known as the "Mad Caliph") orders the destruction of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem. The subsequent persecution of Christians lasts for more than a decade.[1][2]

1027

  • The Holy Sepulchre is rebuilt after a Byzantine–Fatimid treaty.[3]

1055

  • December 18. The Seljuk ruler Tughril becomes the Abbasids caliphs' protector.[4]

1063

  • A Byzantine-Fatimid treaty strengthens the Byzantine emperors' position as the patron of the Christians in the Fatimid Caliphate.[4]

before 1071

  • Merchants from Amalfi establish the Benedictine Saint Mary of the Latins Abbey in Jerusalem.[5]

1071

  • August 21. The Seljuks overcome the Byzantines in the Battle of Manzikert and invade Asia Minor.[6][7]
  • A Seljuk commander, Atsiz ibn Uvaq, captures Jerusalem.[6]

1074

  • March 1. Pope Gregory VII urges his German and French supporters to assist the Byzantines against the Seljuks.[8][9]

1080s

  • The Gregorian theologians, Anselm of Lucca, Bonizo of Sutri and John of Mantua complete the Roman Catholic ideology of holy wars.[9]
  • A hospital dedicated to Saint John the Baptist is established in Jerusalem under the auspices of the Saint Mary of the Latins Abbey.[5]

1095

  • March. The Byzantine Emperor Alexios I Komnenos's envoys seek the support of Pope Urban II for recruiting mercenaries against the Seljuks.[10]
  • November 27. At the Council of Clermont, Pope Urban II proclaims the First Crusade for the liberation of the Holy Land.[11][12]
  • December 1. Raymond IV, Count of Toulouse is the first ruler to join the crusade, but the Pope denies to make him its supreme commander.[11][13]

1096

  • August 15. Godfrey of Bouillon, Duke of Lower Lotharingia, departs for the crusade. His brother, Baldwin of Boulogne, and their kinsman, Baldwin of Bourcq, accompany him.[11][12]

1097

  • c. January 20. Godfrey swears fealty to Alexios I in Constantinople.[14]

1098

  • March. The crusaders send envoys to the Fatimid Caliphate, offering their assistance against the Seljuks in return for Jerusalem.[15]
  • July 3. A month after the capture of Antioch, the crusaders decide to delay the military campaign because of the hot summer.[16]
  • August 26. Al-Afdal, the Fatimid vizier, expels the Seljuks from Jerusalem.[16]
  • October 18. Simeon II, the exiled Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem, and the papal legate, Adhemar of Le Puy, urge the European warriors to join the crusade in a common letter.[17]

1099

  • January 13. Raymond IV and Tancred of Hauteville depart from the recently captured Maarrat al-Nu'man to continue the crusade.[18]
  • February 14. Raymond IV besieges Arqa because he cannot continue the campaign without other crusader leaders' support.[19]
  • Spring. Al-Afdal refutes to make an alliance with the crusaders, but he offers to grant entry into Jerusalem to unarmed pilgrims.[20]
  • c. April 1. The protracted siege of Arqa forces Raymond IV to seek Godfrey's and Robert II of Flanders' assistance.[21]
  • c. April 10. Byzantine envoys inform the crusaders about Alexios I's plan to invade Palestine in late June.[22]
  • Early May. Ignoring Raymond IV's protests, the crusaders lift the siege of Arqa and depart for Jerusalem without waiting for the arrival of the Byzantine army.[23]

  • Church of the Holy Sepulchre: the site of the crucifixion and resurrection of Jesus, according to Christian tradition

  • Pope Urban II preaching the First Crusade

  • Battle of Manzikert

  • Raymond IV of Toulouse takes the cross

  • The farewell of Ida of Lorraine to her sons, Godfrey of Bouillon and Baldwin of Boulogne departing for the First Crusade

  • Two crusaders swear fealty to the Byzantine Emperor Alexios I Komnenos

First kingdom[edit]

Establishment[edit]

"[As] the Christian victors came back out of the palace after the very great and cruel slaughter of Saracens, of whom ten thousand fell in that same place, they put to the sword great numbers of gentiles who were running about through the quarters of the city, fleeing in all directions on account of their fear of death: they were piercing through with the sword's point women who had fled into the turreted palaces and dwellings; seizing by the soles of their feet from their mothers' laps or their cradles infants who were still suckling and dashing them against the walls or lintels of the doors and breaking their necks; they were slaughtering some with weapons, or striking them down with stones; they were sparing absolutely no gentile of any age or kind."

The slaughter of the townspeople in Jerusalem (from Albert of Aachen's Historia Hierosolymitanae expeditionis)

"[On] the eighth day after the city was captured, they elected Duke Godfrey as prince of the city that he might fight the pagans and guard the Christians. Likewise, on the day of Saint Peter in Chains, they elected as patriarch a most wise and honorable man named Arnulf."

Godfrey of Bouillon is elected the first crusader ruler of Jerusalem (from the Gesta Francorum et aliorum Hierosolimitanorum)

1099

  • May 19. The crusaders cross the Dog River.[24]
  • June 3. The crusaders seize Ramla and make it the see of a Roman Catholic bishopric.[25][26]
  • June 7. The crusaders reach Jerusalem.[25][27]
  • June 17. A Genoese fleet captures Jaffa.[28][29]
  • Early July. Tancred captures Bethlehem and places his banner over the Church of the Nativity, outraging the clergymen who demand that the Holy Land be transformed into a spiritual realm, protected by secular lords.[30][31]
  • c. July 15. The Saint John the Baptist Hospital becomes independent of the Saint Mary of the Latins Abbey.[5]
  • July 15. The crusaders capture Jerusalem and massacre almost all local Muslims and Jews.[32][33]
  • July 22. The crusaders elect Godfrey the ruler of Jerusalem, but he is not crowned king.[34][35]
  • Late July. Raymond IV denies to cede the Tower of David to Godfrey, but his deputy allows Godfrey's soldiers to take possession of it.[34]
  • August 1. Arnulf of Chocques is elected the first Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem. He expels the local Christian—Armenian, Copt, Jacobite, and Nestorian—clergy from the Holy Sepulchre.[36][37]
  • August 12. Battle of Ascalon: the crusaders route Al-Afdal's army.[38][37]
  • c. August 30. Most crusaders leave the Holy Land for Europe.[39][40]
  • Early September. A Pisan fleet arrives at Syria under the command of Daimbert, Archbishop of Pisa.[41]
  • October 15–December 15. Godfrey unsuccessfully besieges Arsuf.[42]
  • December 21. Daimbert, Bohemond I (the first crusader prince of Antioch), and Godfrey's brother, Baldwin (the first count of Edessa), come to Jerusalem, accompanied by thousands of pilgrims.[25]
  • December 25. Arnulf abdicates and Daimbert is elected the new Latin patriarch. Godfrey and Bohemond I swear fealty to Daimbert.[43]

1100

  • February. The emirs (or rulers) of Ascalon, Caesarea and Acre pay tribute to Godfrey to prevent him from making plundering raids.[42]
  • February 2. Godfrey cedes the fourth of Jaffa to Daimbert.[44]
  • April 1. Godfrey promises to cede Jerusalem to Daimbert after the conquest of Ascalon.[45]
  • Early April. The Pisan fleet sails for Italy.[46]
  • c. June 10. The Doge of Venice Vitale I Michiel arrives at Jaffa at the head of a fleet of 200 ships. His treaty with Godfrey's representatives establishes the Venetians' right to have their own quarter and church in the towns in the Holy Land.[46]
  • July 18. Godfrey dies unexpectedly.[41]
  • c. July 22. Godfrey's retainers seize the Tower of David in Jerusalem and urge his brother, Baldwin, to claim Jerusalem.[47]
  • c. August 1. Daimbert sends envoys to Bohemond I, asking him to prevent Baldwin from coming to Jerusalem.[48]
  • c. August 15. Danishmend Gazi captures Bohemond I near Melitene.[41]
  • August 20. Tancred's troops and the Venetians capture Haifa and massacre the townspeople.[46]
  • October 2. Baldwin grants Edessa to Baldwin of Bourcq and departs for Jerusalem.[49]
  • Late October. Baldwin's supporters prevent Tancred from seizing Jerusalem and Jaffa. Daimbert takes refugee at a monastery on Mount Zion.[50]
  • November 9. The burghers of Jerusalem ceremoniously receive Baldwin.[50][51]
  • November 15–December 21. Baldwin makes raids as far as Ascalon and Wadi Musa.[50]
  • December 25. Daimbert crowns Baldwin king in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem.[51][52]

  • Godfrey of Bouillon during the siege of Jerusalem in 1099

  • The conquest of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099

  • Godfrey of Bouillon is elected the first Latin ruler of Jerusalem

  • Battle of Ascalon

  • Godfrey of Bouillon receives his brother, Baldwin I of Edessa, at Jerusalem

  • Baldwin I's coronation

Consolidation[edit]

"[The keeper of the key of the Tomb of Jesus] led me barefoot alone into the holy tomb of the Lord with the lamp which I had brought with me, and told me to place it on the Lord's tomb. And with my own sinful hands I placed it at the place where the most pure feet of Our Lord Jesus Christ lay; at the head stood the lamp of the Greeks and at the breast the lamp of [the Greek Orthodox monastery] of Saint Saba... . And then by the grace of God these three lamps were lit, but of the Frankish lamps which had been hung higher up not one was lit. ... In the morning of Holy Saturday ... all the people gather before the church of the holy Resurrection, a great multitude, both natives of that country and travellers from every land... . ... And the faithful weep torrents of tears ..., for every man then looks into himself and recalls his sins and each says within himself: "Can it be that the holy light will not descend on account of my sins?" ... [Baldwin I] sent to the hospice of Saint Saba and summoned the abbot and his monks. And the abbot went with his brethren to the tomb of the Lord... . ... [Baldwin I] commanded the abbot of Saint Sabba to stand above the tomb with his monks... . ... The Latin priests stood on the Great Altar. And ... the orthodox priests and monks ... began to sing vespers, while the Latins ... began mumbling after their own fashion. ... Then suddenly the holy light shone in the holy tomb and a fearful bright flash came from the holy tomb of the Lord. The bishop with four deacons ... took the candle from [Baldwin I], went into the tomb and lit [Baldwin I's] candle ... first from the Holy Fire... ."

Daniel the Traveller's account of the ceremony of the Holy Fire

"[Al-Afdal] sent his son, Sharaf al-Ma'ālī, at the head of a large force. They and the Franks met at Yāzūr near Ramla. The Franks suffered a defeat and there was a great slaughter among them. ... When Baldwin saw how serious things were, he feared death or captivity, so threw himself into the grass and hid. Once the Muslims were some distance away, he emerged and went to Ramla. ... [Sharaf al-Ma'ālī's] followers disagreed about their next objective. Some said, "Let us attack Jerusalem and conquer it." Others said, "Let us attack Jaffa and take it." While they disagreed in this way, a large host of Franks arrived by sea, intending a pilgrimage to Jerusalem. Baldwin directed them to join him on an expedition. They marched to Ascalon, where Sharaf al-Ma'ālī was. He was not strong enough to resist them but God was kind to the Muslims. The Franks from overseas saw how strong Ascalon was and feared a night attack, so they withdrew to Jaffa. [Sharaf al-Ma'ālī] returned to his father ... ."

Second Battle of Ramla (from Ali ibn al-Athir's Chronicle)

1101

  • January–February. Geldemar Carpenel accuses Tancred of having unlawfully deprived him of Haifa, but Tancred does not answer the charges.[53]
  • early March. After Tancred departures for Antioch to deputize for Bohemond I, Baldwin I distributes his domains between Geldemar Carpenel and Hugh of Fauquembergues. A papal legate, Maurice of Porto, comes to Jerusalem.[54]
  • Easter. A Genoese fleet arrives at Jaffa.[55] The Greek Orthodox monks are allowed to return to the Holy Sepulchre to secure the celebration of the Holy Fire.[51]
  • May 9. Baldwin I and the Genoese capture Arsuf.[55]
  • May 17. Baldwin I and the Genoese capture Caesarea.[55]
  • August–September. The Seljuk Sultan of Rum Kilij Arslan I and his allies massacre most crusaders of the Crusade of 1101 in three battles in Asia Minor.[56][57]
  • September 7. First Battle of Ramla: Baldwin I routes a Fatimid army, losing one-third of his army in the battlefield.[58]
  • Winter. Daimbert is deposed at a council in the presence of the papal legate.[52][59]

1102

  • Easter. Stephen, Count of Blois, Stephen I, Count of Burgundy and other survivors of the Crusade of 1101 stay in Jerusalem.[59][58]
  • May 17. Second Battle of Ramla: Al-Afdal's son, Sharaf al-Ma'ali, almost annihilates the Franks. Baldwin I appeals for help to Tancred.[58][60]
  • May 28. After gathering new troops, Baldwin forces Sharaf al-Ma'ali to return to Egypt.[59][58][60]
  • late May. Tancred tries to achieve Daimbert's restoration, but the new papal legate, Robert of St Eusebio, confirms Daimbert's deposition. A pious cleric, Evremar, is appointed as the Latin patriarch.[61][62]

1103

  • April. Baldwin I besieges Acre, but cannot capture it.[63]
  • July. Baldwin I is seriously wounded in a skirmish near Caesarea.[64]

1103–1106

  • Baldwin I forces his Armenian wife (now known as Arda) into a monastery, but later allows her to move to Constantinople.[65][66]

c. 1104

  • The Jacobite metropolitan of Jerusalem Ignatius II persuades Baldwin I to restore the estates of his see to him.[67]

1104

  • May 26. Baldwin I captures Acre with the assistance of Genoese and Pisan fleets.[63]
  • Autumn. Daimbert sails for Italy to achieve his restoration in Rome.[62][68]

1105

  • February 28. Raymond IV dies and his cousin, William Jordan continues the siege of Tripoli.[68]
  • August 27. Third Battle of Ramla: Baldwin I defeats the united Fatimid and Seljuk armies.[69]

1107

  • Pope Paschal II reinstates Daimbert as patriarch.[62]
  • June 16. Daimbert dies in Messina.[62]

1108

  • The new papal legate, Archbishop Ghibbelin of Arles, deposes Evremar at a church council. Ghibbelin is elected as the Latin patriarch.[70]

1109

  • March. Raymond IV's son, Bertrand, lays claim to Raymond IV's inheritance against William Jordan. William Jordan makes an alliance with Tancred and Bertrand swears fealty to Baldwin I.[68]
  • April. Baldwin I summons Tancred and Tancred's opponents, Bertrand, Baldwin II of Edessa and Joscelin of Courtenay to a general assembly at the crusaders' camp at Tripoli in the name of the "whole church of Jerusalem". The assembly confirms Bertrand's claim to Tripoli and Baldwin I grants Galilee to Tancred.[71][72]
  • July 12. The crusaders capture and sack Tripoli. Baldwin I grants a safe-conducts to the burghers, but he cannot prevent the Genoese from killing many of them.[73][74]

1110

  • May 12. Baldwin I and a Genoese fleet capture Beirut. The crusaders massacre the townspeople.[73][75]
  • early summer. Baldwin I and Bertrand make a joint military campaign against Mawdud, the atabeg of Mosul, to protect Edessa.[73][75]
  • December 4. Baldwin I, Sigurd I of Norway and a Venetian fleet capture Sidon.[75]

1111

  • February 17 and 24. A qadi from Aleppo, Ibn al-Khashshab, a Hashemite sharif, and many Muslim commoners urge the Seljuk Sultan Muhammad I Tapar in the principal mosques in Bagdad to start a holy war against the crusaders.[76][77]
  • Baldwin I and Patriarch Ghibbelin persuade the Pope to confirm the jurisdiction of the Latin Patriarchs of Jerusalem over the newly established bishoprics of Sidon and Beirut, ignoring the traditional boundary between the patriarchal sees of Antioch and Jerusalem.[78]

1112

  • Lent. Patriarch Ghibbelin dies.[79]
  • December. Arnoulf of Chocques elected as the Latin patriarch.[80]

1113

  • May–June. Mawdud and Toghtekin, the atabeg of Damascus, invade Galilee.[76][77]
  • June 28. Battle of Al-Sannabra: Mawdud and Toghtekin defeat Baldwin I.[81][82]
  • July–August. Mawdud makes raids as far as Ascalon.[82]
  • August. Baldwin I marries the wealthy Adelaide del Vasto after promising to name her son, Roger II of Sicily, as his heir.[83][66]
  • Late. Pope Paschal II confirms the autonomy of the monks of the Saint John the Baptist Hospital (or Hospitallers).[82][84]

1114

  • The canons of the Holy Sepulchre adopt the Rule of St. Augustine.[82][85]

1115

  • The papal legate, Berengar, Bishop of Orange, deposes Patriarch Arnulf primarily for Baldwin I's bigamious marriage.[85]
  • Pagan is the first chancellor of Jerusalem.[86]
  • The construction of Montreal Castle in Oultrejordain begins.[87]

1116

  • Baldwin I orders the construction of castles near Petra and Aqaba to control the caravan routes between Egypt and Syria.[86]

1117

  • April 25. Adelaide departs for Sicily after her marriage to Baldwin I was annuled at a church council convoked by Arnoulf of Chocques.[88]
  • July 19. The Pope appoints Arnoulf of Chocques as the Latin patriarch.[88]

1118

  • March. Baldwin I invades Egypt but he falls seriously ill in Pelusium.[87][89]
  • April 2. Baldwin I dies at Arish. Envoys are sent to his brother, Eustace III, Count of Boulogne, offering him the throne.[87][89][90]
  • April 14. Baldwin II of Edessa comes to Jerusalem. Patriarch Arnulf and Joscelin of Courtenay achieve his election as Baldwin I's successor.[87][91]
  • Late April. Patriarch Arnulf dies. Baldwin II secures the direct royal control of the most important towns and the noblemen swear fealty to him at a general assembly.[92]
  • May. Toghtekin demands Oultrejourdain from Baldwin and invades Galilee. Al-Afdal gathers his troops at Ascalon and Toghtekin joins him.[91][93]
  • May–July. Baldwin II and troops from Antioch and Tripoli prevent Al-Afdal and Toghtekin from launching a joint campaign against the kingdom.[94]
  • Late summer. Baldwin II invades Damascene territory and routes Toghtekin's son, Taj al-Muluk Buri.[94]
  • August–September. Warmund of Picquigny is elected the Latin patriarch.[95]

1119

  • Patriarch Warmund confirms the religious community established by Hugues de Payens and other knights to protect the pilgrims. Baldwin II cedes a part of the royal palace, identified as Solomon's Temple, to them (hence they are known as Templars).[93][96][97]
  • June 28. Battle of the "Field of Blood": the Artuqid ruler of Mardin Ilghazi almost annihilates the Antiochene army.[93][98]
  • Late July. Baldwin II is acknowledged as regent for the absent minor prince of Antioch, Bohemond II.[93][99]
  • August 14. Battle of Hab: Baldwin II forces Ilghazi and Toghtekin to withdraw from Antiochene territory.[100][101]
  • August–September. Baldwin II grants the County of Edessa to Joscelin.[102]
  • December 25. Baldwin II is crowned king in Bethlehem.[90]

1120

  • January 16. Council of Nablus: the Jerusalemite prelates and noblemen adopt laws against sexual misconduct and confirm the right of the Church to collect the tithe.[103]
  • January 23. Baldwin II appeals to Pope Calixtus II and to Venice for assistance against the Muslim powers.[104]
  • May. Fulk V, Count of Anjou comes to the Holy Land.[105]
  • June. Ilghazi invades Antiochene territories. Baldwin II returns to Syria, ignoring his Jerusalemite vassals' opposition to the campaign.[106]

1120s

  • The canons of the Holy Sepulchre open a school.[107]

1121

  • April–June. Baldwin II conducts a series of military expeditions in Syria.[108]
  • June. Toghtekin invades Galilee, forcing Baldwin II to return from Syria.[109]
  • July. Baldwin II captures and destroys the fortress built by Toghtekin at Jerash in the previous year.[104]
  • August–October. Baldwin II conducts new campaigns in Syria.[108]

1122

  • January. Fulk V hires 100 knights for the defence of the Holy Land before his departure for Europe.[105]
  • Early. Baldwin II forces Pons, Count of Tripoli into obedience.[110]
  • September 13. Joscelin I is captured by Nur al-Daulak Balak.[111]
  • Autumn. Baldwin II appoints Geoffrey of Marash to administer the County of Edessa.[111]

1123

  • April 18. Balak captures Baldwin II in Syria.[111]
  • Late April. Patriarch Warmund convokes a general assembly which elects Eustace Grenier as baillif (or regent) for the captive Baldwin II.[112][113]
  • May. The Doge of Venice Domenico Michiel arrives at Jaffa and the Venetians defeat a Fatimid fleet.[112][114]
  • May 29. Fatimid troops invade the kingdom, but the Jerusalemite army defeat them near Ibelin.[114]
  • June 15. Eustace Grenier dies. William I of Bures is elected as baillif.[112]
  • December. Pactum Warmundi: Patriarch Warmund, William I of Bures and the chancellor, Pagan, grant privileges to the Venetians.[112][114]

1124

  • February 16. The Venetians and the Franks lay siege to Tyre.[114][115]
  • July 7 or 8. The fall of Tyre to the Franks.[114][115]
  • August 29. Ilghazi son's, Timurtash, releases Baldwin II for ransom.[116]

  • Second Battle of Ramla (1102)

  • Third Battle of Ramla (1105)

  • Baldwin I repudiates Adelaide del Vasto

  • Baldwin I's funeral

  • Baldwin II's coronation

  • Baldwin II and the founders of the Knights Templar

Heyday[edit]

1124

  • October 6. Baldwin II lays siege to Aleppo.[114]
  • Late. Timurtash refuses to assist the burghers of Aleppo. Ibn al-Khashshab turns to the atabeg of Mosul Aqsunqur al-Bursuqi for assistance.[114][117]

1125

  • January 25. Al-Bursuqi forces Baldwin II to lift the siege of Aleppo and units Aleppo with Mosul.[118][119]
  • April 3. Baldwin II returns to Jerusalem for the first time since 1121.[118]
  • May 2. Privilegium Balduini: Baldwin II modifies the terms of the Pactum Warmundi to strengthen royal authority.[118][120]
  • June 11. Baldwin II, Pons and Joscelin I defeat the united forces of Al-Bursuqi and Toghtekin near Azaz.[121]

1126

  • Late January. Baldwin II defeats Toghtekin on the plain of Marj al-Saffar.[122][123]
  • March–July. Baldwin II and Pons conduct joint campaigns in Syria.[118]
  • October. Bohemond II comes to Antioch and marries Baldwin II's daughter, Alice.[124]

1127

  • April. The Seljuk Sultan Mahmud II appoints Imad ad-Din Zengi to administer Mosul and Aleppo.[125][126]
  • October. William I of Bures is sent to France to offer the hand of Baldwin II's eldest daughter, Melisende, to Fulk V of Anjou.[124][127]

1127

  • Summer. Baldwin II mediates a reconciliation between Bohemond II and Joscelin I in Syria.[128]

1128

  • January. Zengi's troops capture Aleppo.[125]
  • July 27. Patriarch Warmund dies.[129][130]
  • Summer or Autumn. Baldwin II's relative, Stephen of La Ferté, is made the Latin patriarch.[129][130]

1129

  • January. The Templars' Latin Rule is confirmed at the Council of Troyes.[131][132]
  • May. Fulk V comes to Jerusalem and marries Melisende after Baldwin II promises to appoint him as his sole heir.[132]
  • September 4. Toghtekin's son and successor, Taj al-Muluk Buri, orders a purge against the Assassins in Damascus. Their leader Ismail al-Ajami offers to cede Banias to Baldwin II.[132][133]
  • November. The Franks seize Banias and invade Damascene territory, but Buri routes them on Marj al-Saffar.[132][134]

c. 1130

  • Patriarch Stephen demands Jaffa from Baldwin II.[129][135]

1130

  • February. Bohemond II is killed during a raid and the Antiochene lords offer the regency for his daughter by Alice, Constance, to Baldwin II. Alice seeks Zengi's assistance against Baldwin II, but he seizes Antioch without resistance and appoints Joscelin I to administer it.[136]
  • June. Patriarch Stephen dies. His successor, William of Malines, abandons Stephen's claims to Jaffa.[129][137]

1131

  • August. The dying Baldwin II names Fulk, Melisende and their son, Baldwin as his co-heirs.[138][139]
  • August 21. Baldwin II dies in Jerusalem.[132]
  • September 14. Fulk and Melisende are crowned in the Holy Sepulchre. Fulk starts replacing his late father-in-law's officials with his own supporters.[140][141][142]

1132

  • Summer. Alice and Pons conclude an alliace against Fulk, but Fulk prevents her from assuming the regency in Antioch and defeats Pons near Chastel Rouge.[140][143]
  • December 21. Buri's son and successor, Shams-ul-Mulk Isma'il, captures Banias.[143]

1133

  • Spring. Fulk and Pons defeat Turkmen raiders. Fulk overcomes Zengi's general, Sawar, near Qinnasrin.[140]
  • Patriarch Stephen begins the construction of Chastel Hernaut to protect the pilgrims on the road between Jaffa and Jerusalem.[140][144]

1134

  • Late. Walter I Grenier accusses his stepfather, Hugh II of Jaffa, of plotting against Fulk. Hugh rose up and persuades the Fatimids to send reinforcements to him from Ascalon. Patriarch William mediates a reconciliation and Hugh leaves for Italy.[145][146]
  • Fulk orders the construction of a castle at Bethgibelin near Ascalon.[144]

c. 1135

  • Fulk commissiones a splendid psalter for Melisende.[107]

1135

  • August. Fulk allows Alice to return to Antioch.[145]

1136

  • April. Fulk's candidate, Raymond of Poitiers, marries Constance in Antioch.[145]
  • Fulk grants Bethgibelin to the Hospitallers.[144]

1137

  • July 11. Battle of Ba'rin: Zengi defeats Fulk and Raymond II, Count of Tripoli.[145][147]
  • September. The Byzantine Emperor John II Komnenos besieges Antioch. Fulk authorizes Raymond to swear fealty to the Emperor.[145][148]

1138

  • February 5. Melisende establishes the Saint Lazarus Abbey at Bethany and appoints her sister, Yvetta, as its first abbess.[149]
  • July. The archbishop of Tyre Fulcher of Angouleme cannot persuade Pope Innocent II to restore the authority of Tyre over bishoprics in the County of Tripoli and the Principality of Antioch. In retaliation for Fulcher's independent action, Patriarch William takes direct control of the see of Tyre and its suffragans.[150]

1139

  • Pope Innocent II orders Patriarch William to restore the see of Tyre to Archbishop Fulcher.[151]
  • Summer. Fulk and his son-in-law, Thierry, Count of Flanders, capture a cave fortress at Ajloun.[152]
  • December. The commander of the Damascene army, Mu'in ad-Din Unur, makes an alliance with Fulk and offers Banias to him.[153][154]

1140

  • May. Zengi besieges Damascus, but the gathering of Jerusalemite troops near Tiberias forces him to lift the siege.[155]
  • June 12. Jerusalemite and Damascene troops capture Banias.[153][156]

1141

  • The papal legate, Bishop Alberic of Ostia, consecrates the Dome of the Rock, transforming it into a church.[157]

1142

  • Castle Blanchegarde is built near Ascalon and Kerak is erected in Oultrejourdain.[144][158]
  • December 25. Patriarch William crowns and anoints Fulk and Melisende's son, Baldwin III, in the Holy Sepulchre. Melisende is crowned for the second time together with her son.[158][159]

1143

  • November 10. Fulk dies after a riding accident.[160]
  • Melisende appoints her cousin, Manasses of Hierges, as constable.[161]

1144

  • Spring. Baldwin III crushes a riot in Wadi Musa.[162][163]
  • December 24. Zengi captures Edessa before the relieving army sent by Melisende reaches the town.[162]

  • Baldwin II's death

  • Coronation of Fulk and Melisende

  • A page from the Melisende Psalter: the capture of Jesus

  • Entrance to Saint Lazar's tomb in Bethany

  • Ruins of Kerak

  • Fulk's funeral

Towards Muslim unity[edit]

See also: Crusader invasions of Egypt

1145

  • September 25. Patriarch William dies.[164]
  • November. Envoys are sent from the crusader states to European rulers seeking their assistance for the recovery of Edessa.[162]
  • December 1. The bull Quantum praedecessores: Pope Eugenius III urges King Louis VII of France to launch a new crusade.[162][165]

1146

  • January 25. Fulcher of Angouleme is elected as the Latin patriarch.[164]
  • September 14. An eunuch slave murders Zengi. Zengi's younger son, Nur ad-Din, seizes Aleppo.[166][167]

1147

  • Spring. Baldwin III's raid against the fertile Hauran region near Damascus outrages Unur.[168]
  • May–June. Nur ad-Din forces Baldwin III to withdraw from Damascene territory.[169][170]

1148

  • Melisende donates a village to the Jacobite metropolitanate of Jerusalem.[171]
  • March 19. Louis VII and the French crusaders reach Antioch.[172]
  • c. April 15. Conrad III of Germany and the German crusaders land at Acre.[172]
  • June 24. Council of Acre: Louis VII, Conrad III, Melisende, Baldwin III and other crusader leaders decide to conquer Damascus.[172][173]
  • July 23–27. The crusaders besiege Damascus, but forces coming from Muslim force them to lift the siege.[172][171]
  • September 8. Conrad III and his army leave the Holy Land.[172]

1149

  • May. Louis VII and the French crusaders depart for France.[174]
  • June 29. Battle of Inab: Nur ad-Din's general, Shirkuh, defeats and kills Raymond of Poitiers.[175][176]
  • July 15. Patriarch Fulcher consecrates the Romanesque basilica of the Holy Sepulchre.[177]
  • August. Baldwin III leads a relief army to Antioch.[176]

1150

  • May. Baldwin III grants the newly built castle of Gaza to the Templars. The fortress prevents the Fatimids from supplying Ascalon on overland routes.[178][179]
  • May 4. Turkoman raiders capture Joscelin II.[180]
  • May–June. Baldwin III vainly summons his mother's supporters to join his campaign to Syria. He authorizes Joscelin II's wife, Beatrice, to sale the remnants of the County of Edessa to the Byzantine Empire.[181][182]

1150s

  • Baldwin III orders the collection of all coins and the issue of new deniers and oboles to secure the royal control of coinage.[183]

1151

  • Melisende makes her younger son, Amalric, the count of Jaffa.[184]
  • Spring. Baldwin III invades the Hauran, forcing Nur ad-Din to lift the siege of Damascus.[178]
  • July. A Fatimid fleet makes a raid along the coast between Jaffa and Tripoli.[178]
  • Late. Assassins murder Raymond II. Baldwin III persuades the Tripolitan lords to swear allegiance to the minor Raymond III of Tripoli and his mother, Hodierna of Jerusalem.[178][185]

1152

  • April. Baldwin III demands the division of the kingdom from his mother. He appoints Humphrey II of Toron as constable and captures Manasses of Hierges' castle at Mirabel. He forces Melisende to abdicate and deprives Amalric of Jaffa.[186]

1153

  • January 25. The crusaders lay siege to Ascalon.[187]
  • Spring. Baldwin III gives consents to the marriage of Constance of Antioch and Raynald of Châtillon.[184][188]
  • Early June. A Fatimid fleet defeats the Jerusalemite squadron at Ascalon.[189]
  • August 23. The Franks capture Ascalon, thus completing the conquest of the Western coast of the Mediterranean Sea.[190][191]

1154

  • Baldwin III restores Jaffa to Amalric and also grants Ascalon to him.[192]
  • April 25. Nur ad-Din captures Damascus, uniting the Muslim lands in Syria under his rule.[191]

1155

  • June. Nur ad-Din and Baldwin III conclude a one-year truce.[190][193]
  • October–November. Patriarch Fulcher and most of his suffragans accuse the Hospitallers of abusing their privileges, but Pope Hadrian IV does not condemn the knights.[177]

1156

  • June. The truce of the previous year is renewed for a year. Nur ad-Din pays a tribute to Baldwin III.[190][193]

1157

  • May. Nur ad-Din besieges Banias.[190][193]
  • June 19. Baldwin III forces Nur ad-Din to lift the siege of Banias.[193][194]
  • July. Nur ad-Din again besieges Banias, but the united armies of Baldwin III, Raymond III and Raynald force him to withdraw his troops.[195][196]
  • September. Baldwin III's brother-in-law, Thierry, Count of Flanders, and Flemish crusaders land at Beirut.[196]
  • November. The united crusader forces capture Shaizar. Baldwin III grants it to Thierry, but after a debate between Thierry and Raynald about its status, the crusaders abandon it.[197]
  • November 20. Patriarch Fulcher dies.[198]
  • Late. Baldwin III's half-sister, Sibylla, and aunt, Yvetta, achieve the election of a French cleric, Amalric of Nesle, as the Latin patriarch. The archbishop of Caesarea and the bishop of Bethlehem appeal to the Holy See against his election.[199]

1158

  • February. The united crusader forces capture Haram.[200]
  • Spring. Baldwin III and Thierry make a raid against Damascene territory.[195][200]
  • May. Nur ad-Din besieges the castle of Habis Jaldak near Tiberias.[195][200]
  • July 15. Baldwin III and Thierry relieve Habis Jaldak.[195][200]
  • September. Baldwin III marries a niece of the Byzantine Emperor Manuel I Komnenos, Theodora.[201]
  • Late. Pope Hadrian IV confirms Amalric of Nesle's election as patriarch.[199]

1159

  • Spring. After lengthy negotiations, Manuel I and Baldwin III conclude an alliance against Nur ad-Din near Antioch.[202]
  • April 12. Baldwin III and Raynald ceremoniusly receive Manuel I in Antioch.[203]
  • May. After Nur ad-Din releases his Christian prisoners and offers an alliance against th Seljuks of Rum, Manuel I leaves Syria for Constantinople.[204]
  • Baldwin III persuades the prelates and barons to remain neutral in the conflict between Pope Alexander III and his rival, Victor IV at their general assembly in Nazareth, but later the prelates acknowledge Alexander III as the lawful pope.[199]

1160

  • November. After Nur ad-Din's soldiers capture Raynald, Baldwin III appoints the Latin patriarch of Antioch, Aimery of Limoges to administer Antioch.[205][206]

1161

  • September 11. Melisende dies.[205]

1163

  • February 10. Baldwin III dies childless in Beirut.[207]
  • c. February 15. The prelates and barons elect Baldwin III's brother, Amalric, as king only after Amalric's marriage to Agnes of Courtenay is annulled. Amalric achieves the confirmation of their children's right to succeede him.[208]
  • February 18. Amalric is crowned king.[209]
  • September. Amalric besieges Bilbeis in Egypt. The Egyptian cut the dikes, forcing him to lift the siege.[210]

c. 1164

  • Amalric's Assise sur la ligece obliges the vassals of his own vassals to swear fealty directly to him.[211]

1164

  • Early. Amalric urges Louis VII to send reinforcements to the Holy Land in a letter.[209]
  • April. Nur ad-Din sends Shirkuh to Egypt to restore the former Fatimid vizier, Shawar.[212][210][213]
  • May. Shawar denies to pay a tribute to Nur ad-Din. After Shirkuh captures Bilbeis, Shawar seeks Amalric's assistance.[210][214]
  • August–October. Amalric besieges Bilbeis.[215]
  • August 10. Battle of Harim: Nur ad-Din routes the united armies of Bohemond III of Antioch, Raymond III, Thoros II of Armenian Cilicia, and Constantine Kalamanos, the Byzantine governor of Cilicia.[216]
  • September. Nur ad-Din captures Banias.[215]
  • October. Amalric and Shirkuh withdraw their troops from Egypt. Amalric assumes the regency for the captive Raymond III in Tripoli.[215][217]

1167

  • January. Shirkuh invades Egypt. Amalric convokes a general assembly to Nablus which votes a 10 percent tax on movable property to finance a new campaign against Shirkuh.[218][219]
  • January 30. Amalric invades Egypt.[218][220]
  • March. Shawar agrees to pay a yearly tribute to Amalric and the Fatimid Caliph Al-Adid confirms their treaty.[218][221]
  • March 18. Battle of al-Babein: an indecisive engagement between Amalric and Shirkuh's armies.[222]
  • Late March. Shirkuh seizes Alexandria. Amalric besieges it with the assistance of a Pisan fleet.[223]
  • c. August 1. Shirkuh agrees to abandon Alexandria in return for 40,000 dinars. Amalric is authorized to place a garrison in Alexandria. Shawar promises to pay a yearly tribute to Amalric.[223]
  • August 4. Shirkuh and his army depart for Damascus.[223]
  • Late August. Shawar's son, al-Kamil Shuja, offers allegiance to Nur ad-Din.[223]
  • August 29. Amalric marries Manuel I's niece, Maria Komnene, in Tyre. Amalric proposes the division of the declining Fatimid Caliphate between the Byzantine Empire and the Kingdom of Jerusalem to the Emperor's envoys.[220][224]

1168

  • Easter. The Jacobite Patriarch Michael the Syrian meets with Patriarch Amalric in Jerusalem.[225]
  • September. Manuel I accepts Amalric's offer for a joint military campaign against the Fatimid Caliphate.[224][226]
  • Early October. The Grand Master of the Knights Hospitallers, Gilbert of Assailly, promises support to Amalric against Egypt. The Knights Templars decide not to participate in the campaign.[227]
  • November 4. Amalric's troops massacre the Muslim and Coptic townspeople at Bilbeis which stirs up the Egyptians' resistance.[220][228]
  • November 13. Amalric lays siege to Cairo. Al-Adid seeks Nur ad-Din's assistance, but Shawar offers a tribute to Amalric.[220][229][230]
  • December 25. Shirkuh invades Egypt, forcing Amalric lift the siege of Cairo.[220]

1169

  • January 2. Amalric withdraws his troops from Egypt.[231]
  • January 18. Shirkuh's nephew, Saladin, kills Shawar with Al-Adid's approval. Al-Adid appoints Shirkuh as vizier.[231]
  • March 23. Shirkuh dies.[231]
  • March 26. Al-Adid appoints Saladin as vizier.[232]
  • Summer. Amalric sends an embassy to France, England and Sicily to ask for a new crusade.[233]
  • September. A Byzantine fleet arrives at Acre.[234]
  • October–December. The Franks and the Byzantines unsuccessfully besiege Damietta.[235]

c. 1170

  • Amalric's only son and heir, Baldwin, is diagnosed with leprosy.[236]

1170

  • December. Saladin destroys significant parts of Darum and Gaza.[237]

1171

  • Early. New embassy is sent to the European rulers.[238]
  • March–July. Amalric convinces Manuel I to renew their alliance in Constantinople.[239][240]
  • September 13. Al-Adid's death put an end to the Fatimid Caliphate and makes Saladin the undisputed ruler of Egypt.[237][241][242]
  • October. Saladin invades the Kingdom of Jerusalem, but he returns to Egypt when he learns of Nur ad-Din's decision to participate in the campaign. Nur ad-Din accuses Saladin of disloyalty.[243]

1173

  • Outraged by the fall of the Fatimids, the Assassin leader, Rashid ad-Din Sinan, offers to convert to Christianity if the Templars do not tax the Assassins' subjects in Syria. Templars murder Sinan's envoys.[241][244]
  • Summer. Amalric sents a new embassy to Europe.[245]

1174

  • May 15. Nur ad-Din dies in Damascus.[246]
  • June. Amalric besieges Banias, but falls seriously ill.[247]
  • July 11. Amalric dies in Tiberias.[247]

Decline and fall[edit]

1174

  • July 15. The ailing 13-year-old Baldwin IV is crowned king in the Holy Sepulchre. The senechal, Miles of Plancy, rules the kingdom.[236][248]
  • July 28. A Sicilian fleet besieges Alexandria. Conflicts between Miles and Humphrey III prevent the mobilization of the Jerusalemite army.[249]
  • August 1. The Sicilians lift the siege of Alexandria.[247]
  • August. Raymond III claims the regency as Baldwin IV's closest male relative.[250]
  • Early October. Miles is assassinated in Acre. His widow, Stephanie of Milly, accuses Raymond III of plotting against him.[251]
  • Late October. The High Court of Jerusalem elects Raymond III as baillif. He marries the Princess of Galilee, Eschiva of Bures.[252]
  • October–December. Saladin occupies Damascus and Hama, forcing Nur ad-Din's son, As-Salih Ismail al-Malik, to withdraw to Aleppo.[247]

1175

  • January–February. Raymond III leads a relieve army to Hama against Saladin, but he returns to Jerusalem after Saladin releases the hostages held for his ransom.[252]
  • July 22. Saladin and Raymond III conclude a truce.[253]

1176

  • Summer. The atabeg of Aleppo, Gümüshtekin, releases Raynald of Châtillon and Baldwin IV's maternal uncle, Joscelin III of Courtenay.[254]
  • July. Baldwin IV comes of age.[254]
  • July–August. Baldwin IV and Raymond III make raids as far as Damascus.[255]
  • Late August. Baldwin IV appoints Joscelin III as senechal and arranges his marriage with a wealthy heiress, Agnes of Milly.[255][256]
  • September 17. Battle of Myriokephalon: the Seljuk Sultan of Rum Kilij Arslan II overcomes Manuel I's army.[255]
  • November. William Longsword—the eldest son of William V, Marquess of Montferrat—marries Baldwin IV's sister, Sibylla. William is made the count of Jaffa and Ascalon.[257][258]
  • Winter. Raynald is sent to Constantinople to negotiate with Manuel I.[254]

1177

  • Spring. Raynald marries the lady of Oultrejourdain, Stephanie of Milly. Baldwin IV grants Hebron to him.[259][260]
  • June. William Longsword dies.[258][261]
  • Summer. Baldwin IV's health gets worse.[260]
  • August 1. Baldwin IV's cousin, Philip I, Count of Flanders arrives at Acre. He refuses to assume the regency for Baldwin IV.[260]
  • August. A Byzantine fleet arrives at Acre, but the Franks refuse to participate in a joint campaign against Egypt.[260][262]
  • Autumn. Raynald is appointed as "procurator of the kingdom and the army".[263]
  • September. Philip I, Raymond III and Bohemond II launch a military campaign in Syria, taking the bulk of the Jerusalemite army with them.[264]
  • Late November. Saladin launches a sudden attack against Ascalon.[265]
  • November 25. Battle of Montgisard: Baldwin IV routes Saladin.[262][266]

1178

  • January. The birth of William Longsword's posthumous son by Sybilla, Baldwin.[260]
  • October. Baldwin IV orders the building of the fortress La Chastellet at Jacob's Ford.[267][268]

1179

  • February. The grand masters of the Templars and the Hospitallers, Odo de St Amand and Roger de Moulins, sign an agreement to settle their disputes.[263]
  • April. Baldwin IV gives La Chastellet to the Templars. Humphrey III dies after receiving fatal wounds during a raid against Banias. Agnes of Courtney's favorite, Aimery of Lusignan is made as constable.[267][268][269]
  • May. Saladin raids the region of Jacob's Ford.[270]
  • June 10. Battle of Marj Ayyun: Saladin routes Baldwin IV.[271]
  • August 29. Saladin destroys La Chastellet.[267][271]
  • September. Saladin makes raids as far as Beirut and Tyre.[271]

1180

  • April 20. Bohemond II and Raymond III march to Jerusalem unexpectedly. Outraged by their action, Baldwin IV hastily marries off Sybilla to Aimery's brother, Guy of Lusignan.[272][269]
  • May. Saladin accepts Baldwin IV's proposal to a two-year-truce.[262][273]
  • Autumn. Baldwin IV's half-sister, Isabella, is betrothed to Raynald's stepson, Humphrey IV of Toron. Humphrey IV cedes his paternal domains to the king.[274]
  • October 6. Patriarch Amalric dies.[275]
  • October 16. Heraclius, Archbishop of Caesarea is elected as Latin patriarch.[276]

1181

  • January 16. Pope Alexander III calls for a new crusade, emphasizing that the leper Baldwin IV is unable to defend the Holy Land.[277][278]
  • Summer. Ignoring the truce, Raynald attacks a caravan.[279]

1182

  • Spring. Baldwin IV prohibits Raymond III to enter the Kingdom of Jerusalem.[280]
  • April. Andronikos Komnenos' coup in Constantinople puts an end to Frankish influence in the Byzantine Empire.[277][280]
  • Summer. Baldwin IV is to keep the royal army continuously in the field because of a series of raids from Syria and Egypt.[281]
  • August. Saladin besieges Beirut, but Baldwin IV relieves the town.[282][281]
  • September. Baldwin IV recaptures the fort of Habis Jaldak.[283]

1183

  • February. A general council levies an extraordinary tax to cover the increasing defense costs. Raynald's fleet launches a raid on the Red Sea, menacing Mecca and Medina.[283][284][285]
  • June 11. Saladin captures Aleppo.[283]
  • September 29. Saladin invades Galilee.[286]
  • October. Baldwin IV appoints Guy as baillif. The Frank troops assemble at the Springs of Saffuriya and Saladin returns to Syria. Guy's opponents accuses him of losing the opportunity to inflict a decisive defeat on Saladin.[287][288]
  • November. Guy refuses to exchange Jerusalem for Tyre with Baldwin IV. Humphrey IV marries Isabella in Kerak. Saladin besieges Kerak during the wedding.[289]
  • November 20. Baldwin IV orders Patriarch Heraclius to make preparations for the annulment of Guy and Sybilla's marriage. Sybilla's five-year-old son by William Longsword, Baldwin V, is crowned king.[289]
  • December 3 or 4. Baldwin IV and Raymond III relieve Kerak.[290]
  • December. Guy and Sybilla withdraw to Ascalon. Baldwin IV deprives him of Jaffa.[283][291]

1184

  • March 29. Patriarch Heraclius excommunicates William of Tyre, forcing him to abdicate the chancellorship.[292]
  • June. Patriarch Heraclius and the grand masters of the Templars and of the Hospitallers are sent to Europe to ask for a new crusade.[293]
  • Augustus 23–September 5. Second siege of Kerak by Saladin, but Baldwin IV relieves the fortress.[293]
  • October. Guy makes a pillaging raid against a Beduin tribe under royal protection.[291]

1185

  • Early April. The dying Baldwin IV appoints Raymond III as baillif for Baldwin V for ten years, but Joscelin III is made Baldwin V's guardian. The High Court rules that the Pope, the Holy Roman Emperor and the kings of France and England are to choose between Sybilla and Isabella's claims to the throne in case of Baldwin V's premature death.[294][295]
  • c. April 15. Baldwin IV dies.[296]
  • Spring. Saladin and Raymond III sign a truce which enables Saladin to invade Mosul.[297][298]

1186

  • March 4. Izz ad-Din Mas'ud, the emir of Mosul, acknowledges Saladin's sovereignty.[299]
  • July 20–c. September 15. Baldwin V dies. Raymond III leaves Jerusalem before the funeral and summons his partisans to a general assembly at Nablus. Joscelin III takes possession of Jerusalem, Acre and Beirut. Ignoring Raymond III's objections, Raynald and the grand master of the Templars, Gerard de Ridefort, take Sybilla to the Holy Sepulchre and Patriarch Heraclius crowns her queen. Her supporters cannot persuade her to divorce Guy and she crowns him king.[299][300][301]
  • October. Raymond III and his supporters offer the crown to Sybilla's half-sister, Isabella, and her husband, Humphrey IV in Nablus. Humphrey IV fleeds from Nablus and swears fealty to Sybilla and Guy. All his former supporters, but Raymond III and Baldwin of Ibelin, hurry to pay homage to the royal couple. Raymond III seeks Saladin's alliance against Guy.[299][302]

1187

  • Early. Contrary to the truce, Raynald seizes a caravan and Guy cannot persuade him to return the spoils and the prisoners.[303]
  • March 29. Saladin declares the jihad against the crusaders.[303]
  • Late April Raymond III allows Saladin's commander Muzzafar al-Din to march across Galilee.[304]
  • May 1. Battle of Cresson: Muzzafar al-Din annihilates an army of Hospitallers and Templars.[299]
  • May 2. Raymond III's Galilean vassals persuade him to abandon his alliance with Saladin and to make peace with Guy.[305][306]
  • June 26. After gathering more than 30,000 troops, Saladin invades the Kingdom of Jerusalem. The Frank troops start gathering at Saffuriya and the garrisons are reduced to the minimum in most fortresses and towns.[305][307]
  • July 4. Saladin annihilates the army of the Kingdom of Jerusalem in the Battle of Hattin. The Frank commanders fell into captivity. Raynald, the Hospitallers and the Templars are executed.[305][308]
  • July 5. Tiberias surrenders to Saladin.[309]
  • July 9. Saladin captures Acre.[309][307]
  • July 14. William Longsword's brother, Conrad of Montferrat, arrives at Tyre and begins to organise the resistance.[310][311]
  • July 10–August 6. Saladin captures Jaffa, Arsuf, Caesarea, Haifa and Sidon.[311]
  • September 4. Ascalon surrenders to Saladin.[312]
  • October 2. After receiving a free passage to the townspeople for a huge ransum, the defenders of Jerusalem surrender to Saladin.[313][314]

Third Crusade[edit]

1187

  • October. Conrad sends Joscius, Archbishop of Tyre to Europe to ask for a new crusade.[313]
  • October 29. Pope Gregory VIII declares the Third Crusade in his bull Audita tremendi.[313]
  • November 25. Saladin lays siege to Tyre.[315]

1188

  • January 1. Saladin abandons the siege of Tyre.[316]
  • May. Saladin releases Guy.[317]
  • October. A Sicilian fleet arrives at the Holy Land.[318]
  • November Saladin's troops capture Kerak.[318][319]
  • December 6. Safad is captured by Saladin's troops.[318][319]

1189

  • January 5. Belvoir surrenders to Saladin's troops.[320][318]
  • May. Saladin's troops capture Montreal. Only Tyre and Belfort remain under Frank rule in the Kingdom of Jerusalem.[321]
  • August. Guy's brother, Geoffrey I of Lusignan, informs him about the preparations for a new crusade in Europe. They gather 9000 troops and march to Tyre, but Conrad does not allow Guy to enter the town.[321][322]
  • August 26. Guy lays siege to Acre with the support of a Pisan fleet.[321][317]
  • September. Flemish, Danish, Frisian and French crusaders arrive at Acre.[323]
  • October 4. Saladin defeats the crusaders at Acre. Fearing of an epidemic, he leaves Acre, but he appoints his brother, Al-Adil, to command his troops.[324]

1190

  • Easter. Conrad acknowledges Guy as the lawful king in return for the confirmation of his rule of Tyre.[325]
  • June 10. Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor drowns in the Saleph River in Asia Minor during his crusade.[326][327]
  • Summer. Patriarch Heraclius dies at Acre.[328]
  • July 27. Henry II, Count of Champagne arrives at Acre, taking new troops and funds with him.[329]
  • July 29. Sybilla and her two daughters by Guy die at Acre.[326][330]
  • Early October. Frederick VI, Duke of Swabia and the remnants of Frederick I's crusade arrive at Acre.[331]
  • c. November 20. Guy's opponents persuade the papal legate, Ubaldo of Pisa, to annul the marriage of Humphrey IV and Isabella.[331]
  • November 24. Conrad marries Isabella in Tyre to strengthen his position against Guy.[331]

1191

  • April 20. Philip II, King of France, and the French crusaders land at Acre. He acknowledges Conrad's claim to the throne against Guy.[332][333]
  • May 6–June 1. Richard I, King of England conquers Cyprus.[334]
  • May 11. Guy meets with Richard I in Cyprus.[332][334]
  • June 8. Richard I disembarks at Acre.[334]
  • July 12. The garrisons of Acre surrender to the crusaders in return for a safe passage.[335][336]
  • July 24 or 26. Richard I and Philip II confirm Guy's right to rule the kingdom until his death, but they also stipulate that Conrad is to succeed Guy on the throne.[337][338]
  • July 31. Philip II departs for France.[335]
  • August 20. Richard I decides to continue the military campaign and orders the massacre of 2,700 Muslim prisoners.[339]
  • September 7. Battle of Arsuf: Richard I overcomes Saladin.[340][341]
  • September 10. Richard I seizes Jaffa without resistance.[342]
  • October. Richard I offers the hands of his sister, Joan, to Al-Adil, proposing that they could jointly rule the restored kingdom, but she refuses to marry a Muslim.[343][344]
  • c. November 15. Conrad proposes a separate peace to Saladin who informs the crusaders about Conrad's offer.[345]

1192

  • Januar 20. The crusaders seize the abandoned Ascalon.[337]
  • April 16. After Richard decides to return to England, the Frank barons persuade him to acknowlege Conrad as the lawful king.[337]
  • April 28. Assassins murder Conrad in Tyre.[337][346]
  • May. Richard I authorizes Guy to purchase Cyprus from the Templars.[347]
  • May 5. Henry II of Champagne marries Conrad's pregnant widow, Isabella in Acre.[347][348]
  • June 11. The crusaders march as far as Bayt Nuba near Jerusalem, but Richard I decides not to attack the Holy City in fear of being deprived of water.[349]

Second kingdom[edit]

Recovery[edit]

1192

  • September 2. A truce between Saladin and Richard I confirms the Franks' rule on the coast from Tyre to Jaffa.[350][351]
  • October 9. Richard I departs for England.[350]
  • c. October 15. Saladin grants parts of Caymont to Balian of Ibelin and half of Sidon to Reginald of Sidon. Henry I restores Haifa, Caesarea and Arsuf to their previous lords and grants Jaffa to Aimery of Lusignan.[352]

1193

  • March 4. Saladin dies in Damascus. Conflicts between his sons, brothers and nephews end with the disintegration of his empire.[353][354]
  • May. After Henry I limits the Pisans' presence in Acre for their alliance with Guy, the Pisans pillage the coast. Henry I expels them from the entire kingdom and imprisones Guy's brother, Aimery. The barons and the grand masters persuade the king to release Aimery.[355]

c. 1194

  • The canons of the Holy Sepulchre elect Aymar the Monk as the Latin patriarch without consulting with the king. Henry I imprisons them, but Archbishop Joscius mediate a reconciliation. Pope Celestine III confirms Aymar's election.[356]

1194

  • Spring. Leo II of Cilicia captures Bohemond III. Henry I hurries to Sis and persuades Leo to release Bohemond III.[353][357]
  • May. Aimery inherits Cyprus from Guy. He concludes an agreement with Henry I and mediates a reconciliation between Henry I and the Pisans.[353][358]

1195

  • August 1. Pope Celestine III urges Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor to launch a new crusade.[359]

1196

  • Summer. German crusaders arrive at Acre.[360]
  • July. Al-Adil seizes Damascus from Saladin's son, Al-Afdal.[361]

1197

  • Early September. Al-Adil captures Jaffa. The German crusaders ignore Henry I's ban and make raids against Muslim territories.[359][360]
  • September 10. Henry I dies after he falls from the window of the royal palace in Acre.[362][360]
  • c. September 15. Some baron want to offer the throne to Raoul of Saint Omer, but the military orders achieve the election of Aimery as king.[363]
  • October. Aimery marries Isabella. Patriarch Aymar crowns them king and queen. Aimery has his seat at Acre, but he keeps the adminstration of the two realms separate.[364]
  • Late October. The German crusaders and Frank troops seize Sidon and Beirut.[365]
  • November 28. The German crusaders and Frank troops besiege Toron.[365]

1198

  • Early. Aimery accuses Raoul and Hugh II of Saint Omer of an unsuccessful attempt on his life and banishes them from the kingdom. They appeal to their peers, but Aimery does not repeal his decision.[366]
  • February 2. The siege of Toron is abandoned after news of the death of Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor reaches the crusaders' camp.[365]
  • June 1. A new truce with Al-Adil.[364][362]
  • August 15. Pope Innocent III proclaims the Fourth Crusade in the bull Post Miserabile.[367][368]

1200

  • February. Al-Adil takes control of Egypt.[361][368]

1202

  • Spring. Reginald of Dampierre and 300 crusaders land at Acre. They leave for Antioch after Henry I prohibits them to break the truce.[369][370]

1203

  • May. The leaders of the Fourth Crusade decide to attack Constantinople.[371]

1204

  • May. Aimery sends a fleet to raid the Nile Delta.[372][370]
  • April 12. The crusaders capture Constantinople. The establishment of the Latin Empire of Constantinople weakens the position of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, because the new crusader states on the ruins of the Byzantine Empire attract many crusaders from Europe.[373][374]
  • September. Aimery and Al-Adil conclude a six-year truce. The Franks take full control of Sidon, Lydda and Ramla.[373][374]

1205

  • May 1. Aimery dies in Acre.[374]
  • Late. Isabella dies. Her daughter by Conrad, Maria of Montferrat, succeeds her. Isabella's half-brother, John of Ibelin, assumes the regency for the 13-year-old queen.[375][374]

c. 1206

  • The barons propose Maria to the married Peter II of Aragon, but the Pope does not annul Peter's marriage.[376]

1206

  • After being appointed as the Latin patriarch by Pope Innocent III, Albert of Vercelli comes to the Holy Land.[377]

c. 1207

  • Patriarch Albert completes a regulation for the hermits living on Mount Carmel at the request of their head, Brocard.[378]

1208

  • The barons send Aymar, Lord of Caesarea, and Walter of Florence, Bishop of Acre, to France to ask Philip II to appoint a husband for Maria. Philip II names John of Brienne as his candidate.[379][380]

1209

  • The Pope approves John of Brienne's candidacy. The Pope also gave 40,000 marks for the defence of the Holy Land.[381]

1210

  • July. Al-Adil proposes to cede 10 villages if the Franks renew the truce, but the Templars and the prelates prevent the acceptance of the offer.[382][379]
  • September 13. John and his retinue of 300 knight land at Haifa.[379]
  • September 14. John marries Maria in Acre.[379]
  • October 3. John and Maria are crowned in Tyre. Al-Adil's son, Al-Mu'azzam Isa, makes a raid against Acre.[383][379][384]
  • October. John launches a plundering raid as far as the Jordan, seizing much booty.[372]

1211

  • Spring. John sends Walter of Montbéliard to launch a naval raid against the Nile Delta.[372][385]
  • Summer. John sends 50 knights to assist the Templars against Leo in Cilicia.[386]

1212

  • July. John and Al-Adil conclude a six-year truce.[385][387]
  • Late. Maria dies after giving birth to a daughter, Isabella. After some barons challenge John's right to rule the kingdom, he sends his chancellor, Raoul of Merencourt, to the Holy See. The Pope menaces those who do not obey to John with ecclesiastical sanctions.[385][388][378]

1213

  • Early. Hugh I of Cyprus imprisons a group of John's supporters.[389]
  • Late April. Pope Innocent III proclaims the Fifth Crusade in his bull Quia maior.[385]

1214

  • John marries Leo's daughter, Stephanie of Armenia.[385]
  • A cleric murders Patriarch Albert. Raoul of Merencourt is elected as the Latin patriarch.[390][378]

1215

  • Francis of Assisi's disciple, Giles, settles in the Kingdom of Jerusalem.[391]

1217

  • October. The first leaders of the Fifth Crusade, Andrew II of Hungary and Leopold VI of Austria arrive at Acre. Troops from Antioch and Cyprus join the crusaders.[392]
  • November. The crusaders capture Beisan.[385]
  • November 29–December 7. The crusaders cannot capture the Muslim fortress on Mount Tabor.[385][393]

1218

  • Early. Andrew II, Hugh I and Bohemond IV leave the crusaders' camp.[394]
  • Spring. Caesarea is fortified and Château Pèlerin is built on the coast near Acre.[395]
  • May 29. The crusaders, along with troops from Jerusalem and Cyprus, lay siege to Damietta under John's command.[396]
  • August 31. Al-Adil dies. His sons, Al-Kamil and Al-Mu'azzam succeed him in Egypt and Syria, respectively.[397][398]
  • September. Pope Honorius III's legate, Pelagius, arrives at Damietta and assumes the leadership of the crusade.[397][399]

1219

  • May 2. Leo II dies after bequeathing Cilicia to his youngest daughter, Isabella. John lays claim to Cilicia on behalf of his wife and their son.[397][400]
  • October. Al-Kamil offers to cede all lands to the west of the Jordan in Palestine to the crusaders if they abandon the invasion of Egypt. John is willing to accept the offer, but Pelagius rejects it.[398]
  • November 5. The crusaders capture Damietta. John is appointed to rule the town.[397]
  • Late November. Al-Mu'azzam invades the Kingdom of Jerusalem and sacks Caesarea.[401]

1220

  • February. Pope Honorius III confirms John's claim to Cilicia.[400]
  • Easter. Urged by his bailli, Garnier l'Aleman, John returns to Acre.[402]
  • Summer (?). John's wife and their son die and the Pope acknowledges an other claimant as the lawful ruler of Cilicia.
  • October. Al-Mu'azzam destroy the Templars' fortress at Destroit.[403]

1221

  • June. Louis I, Duke of Bavaria and German crusaders arrive at Damietta.[404]
  • July 6. John returns to Damietta.[404][405]
  • July–August. The crusaders march towards Cairo along the Nile, but the flood traps them and Al-Kamil's troops prevents them from returning to Damietta.[404]
  • August 28. Pelagius and Al-Kadil reach an agreement about the evacuation of the crusaders from Egypt. Al-Kadil also offers an eight-year truce.[404][406]
  • September 8. The crusaders leave Damietta.[404]

1222

  • Summer. Parts of Acre are destroyed during an armed conflict between the Pisan and Genoese merchants.[407]
  • October. John, Patriarch Raoul and the grand master of the Hospitallers, Guérin de Montaigu, leave for Europe to ask for a new crusade and to find a husband for his daughter. John appoints Odo of Montbéliard as his baillif.[408][409]

1223

  • March. Pope Honorius III, Frederick II, Holy Roman Empire, John and the grand masters of the military orders agree about the marriage of Frederick II and Isabella. The Emperor promise to allow John to continue to administer the kingdom.[410][411]
  • Summer. John stayes in northeastern France.[412]
  • August 6. John attends the coronation of Louis VIII of France at Reims.[413]
  • November–December. John visits England.[414]

1224

  • May. After making a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostella, John marries Berengaria of León in Burgos.[415]
  • Patriarch Raoul dies.[416]

1225

  • Early. Gerold of Lausanne is appointed as the Latin patriarch.[417]
  • July 25. Frederick II pledges to launch a crusade until August 1227 at his meeting with the Pope in San Germano.[410][418]
  • August. Isabella II is crowned in Tyre before she leaves the kingdom to meet with Frederick II.[419][420]
  • November 9. Frederick II marries Isabella II in Brindisi. The Jerusalemite barons who are present at the wedding pay homage to Frederick II as their king. Frederick II sends Richer, Bishop of Melfi, to the Kingdom of Jerusalem to receive the homage of the local barons.[420][421]

1227

  • August. Frederick II appoints Thomas, Count of Acerra as his baillif in the Kingdom of Jerusalem.[422]
  • September 8. Frederick II sails for the Holy Land, but illnes forces him to return to Italy.[422]
  • September 29. Pope Gregory IX excommunicates Frederick II for the breaking of his crusader oath.[422][423]
  • October. German, French and English crusaders land at Acre and assist the local Franks to fortify the towns. The Teutonic Knights rebuild the castle of Montfort.[420]

1228

  • Spring. Frederick II's marshal, Richard Filangieri, arrives at Acre. He forbids all raids against Muslim territories.[424]
  • April 25. The birth of Conrad, the only son of Frederick II by Isabella II.[422]
  • May 5. Isabella II dies in Andria.[422]
  • June 28. Frederick II sails for the crusade, but the Pope confirms his excommunication.[422][425]
  • Late July. Frederick II receives the homage of the Jerusalemite barons in Limassol. He demands Beirut from John of Ibelin who refers the case to the High Court.[422][424]
  • September 7. Frederick II lands at Acre and starts negotiations with Al-Kamil.[426]

1229

  • February 18. Frederick II and Al-Kamil sign a truce for ten and a half year that restores Jerusalem to the Franks, but they are not allowed to fortify it. The Muslims are allowed to retain the Dome of the Rock and the Al-Aqsa Mosque.[427][428]
  • March 17. Frederick II enters Jerusalem.[429]
  • March 18. Frederick II crowns himself in the Holy Sepulchre.[429]
  • March 19. Peter of Limoges, Archbishop of Caesarea, places Jerusalem under an interdict because of the presence of Frederick II and the Muslims on behalf of Patriarch Gerald.[429][430]

Absent kings[edit]

1229

  • May 1. Frederick II departs for Italy. He appoints Balian Grenier and Garnier l'Aleman as his baillifs.[431][432]
  • Summer. Beduins attack pilgrims on the road from Jaffa to Jerusalem and sack Jerusalem. Alice of Champagne (the daughter of Henry II and Isabella I) lays claim to Jerusalem, arguing that Conrad forfeited the throne because he had failed to come to Jerusalem, but the High Court does not decide the case.[431][432]

1230

  • May. Jerusalemite delegates meet with Frederick II in Foggia, but they cannot convince him to send Conrad to the Kingdom of Jerusalem.[433][434]
  • September 1. Pope Gregory IX lifts Frederick II's excommunication and recognizes him as the lawful ruler of Jerusalem.[433][435]
  • Autumn. Patriarch Gerold lifts the interdict and the Catholic clerics start taking possession of the churches in Jerusalem.[433]
  • Late. Frederick sends Richard Filangieri to confiscate the fiefs of John of Ibelin and his allies. Filangieri besieges Beirut.[433][436]

1231

  • Early. The High Court acknowledges Richard Filangieri as Frederick II's baillif, but maintains that no fiefs can be confiscated without a proper judgement.[433][436]
  • Autumn. Filangieri ignores the High Court's decision and again besieges Beirut. His arbitrary act stirs up strong opposition in the towns.[433][437]

1232

  • February. John of Ibelin march to Beirut, but he cannot relieve the fortress.[437]
  • Spring. The townspeople form a commune in Acre to guard their liberties against Filangieri. John of Ibelin comes to Acre and seizes Frederick II's fleet. He march to Tyre, forcing Filangieri to abandon the siege of Beirut.[438][439]
  • May 2. Battle of Casal Imbert: Filangieri routes John of Ibelin near Tyre. Filangieri tries to conquer Cyprus, but Ibelin sends reinforcements from Acre, Beirut and Tyre to the island. Henry I of Cyprus who supports John of Ibelin comes of age.[440][441]
  • Late May. John of Ibelin concludes an alliance with the Genoese and returns to Cyprus.[442]
  • June 15. Battle of Agridi: John of Ibelin defeats Filangieri in Cyprus.[440]
  • July. Frederick II persuades the Pope to summon Patriarch Gerold to Rome and to order the Latin Patriarch of Antioch, Albert of Rizzato, to represent the Emperor's interests in the kingdom.[443]
  • c. December 31. Frederick II appoints Philip of Maugastel as his baillif in Acre and orders the dissolution of the Commune at Acre. John of Caesarea stirs up a riot and prevents Maugastel from assuming the government. The High Court rules that Frederick II's appointments by letter are invalid and Conrad is to come to the kingdom to appoint a new baillif. The High Court also declares Balian Grenier and Odo of Montbéliard as lawful baillifs, but Filangieri continues to administer Tyre.[444][445]

1233

  • April. John of Ibelin expels Filangieri from Cyprus, forcing him to return to Italy to urge Frederick II to send reinforcements.[440]
  • July 26. Patriarch Gerold sails for Rome.[435][440]

1234

  • August. The Pope urges John of Ibelin to obey the Emperor.[446]
  • Autumn. The Pope proclaims a new crusade to strengthen the defence of the Holy Land by the time the 1229 truce expires. The papal legate, Theodoric, Archbishop of Ravenna, places Acre under interdict for failing to dissolve the Commune.[440][446][447]

1235

  • Early. The Pope cancels the ecclesiastical sanctions against Frederick II's enemies and the townspeople of Acre, fearing of their conversion to Oriental Christianity.[446]
  • October. Jerusalemite troops support the Hospitallers against Al-Muzaffar Umar, the emir of Hama.[448][444]

1236

  • Early. John of Ibelin dies after a riding accident.[448]
  • February. The delegates of the burghers of Acre agree to dissolve the Commune of Acre at their meeting with the Pope, but the townspeople do not ratify the agreement.[449]
  • Spring/Summer. Relationship between the Pope and Frederick II becomes tense after the Emperor's campaigns in Italy.[450]

1237

  • The Pope sends Patriarch Gerold back to the kingdom, also appointing him as papal legate.[435]

1238

  • March 9. Al-Adil dies. His son, Al-Adil II, succeeds him in Egypt, but he is unable to seize Damascus.[451]

1239

  • March 20. The Pope excommunicates Frederick II.[451]
  • September 1. Theobald I, King of Navarre and the first crusaders from France lands at Acre. A Muslim army sacks the undefended Jerusalem.[451][452]
  • November 2. The crusaders leave Acre for Ascalon.[453]
  • November 12. Henry II, Count of Bar, Hugh IV, Duke of Burgundy, Walter of Brienne and other crusader leaders leave the main army to attack an Egyptian army near Gaza.[454]
  • November 13. Battle of Gaza: the Egyptians annihilate the crusaders, killing or capturing more than 1,500 foot-soldiers.[455]

1240

  • June. Al-Adil II is deposed by his brother, As-Salih Ayyub, in Egypt.[447]

Final years[edit]

1291

  • July 31. Beirut surrenders to the Mameluk troops.[456]

Aftermath[edit]

1291

  • August. Pope Nicholas IV calls for a new crusade for the recovery of the Holy Land.[456]
